title: 110_hr5513
content: The Act titled "Stop Adolescent Smoking Without Excessive Bureaucracy Act of 2008" aims to strengthen state laws regarding tobacco product sales to individuals under the age of 18. This involves setting youth compliance targets and enforcement measures. For fiscal year 2010 and beyond, the Secretary can grant funds under section 1921 if the state has a law prohibiting the sale of tobacco products to individuals under 18. It also prohibits minors from purchasing, receiving, or possessing tobacco products in public places, with enforcement by law enforcement agencies. The state law prohibits the sale of tobacco products to individuals under 18 and prohibits minors from purchasing, receiving, or possessing tobacco products in public places. Retailers must notify employees of the law and ensure compliance within 180 days. Employers are also prohibited from violating the law. Employers must ensure compliance with state laws prohibiting the sale of tobacco products to individuals under 18. Employers can rely on valid proof of age or implement a compliance program. Violators may face civil penalties and community service. Some states have delayed the requirement for compliance until fiscal year 2012. In 2011, the requirement for grant recipients under section 1921 applies from fiscal year 2012 onwards. States must set goals to reduce retailer violations of tobacco laws, with decreasing violation rates each fiscal year until 2019. In fiscal years 2017 to 2020 and beyond, the reduction in violation rates for tobacco laws is set at 13%, 12%, 11%, and 10% respectively. States receiving grants must enforce the law to reduce underage access to tobacco products through inspections and reporting to the Secretary. The State must annually report to the Secretary on their enforcement activities, success in meeting goals, and strategies for enforcing tobacco laws. Individuals under 18 can be used for compliance inspections under certain conditions. The State can engage individuals under 18 for compliance inspections under specific conditions, including parental consent and direct supervision. State settlement proceeds must be used for health programs, tobacco control, or economic development. The Secretary must determine noncompliance before granting funds. The Secretary must determine if a State is compliant with specific regulations before granting funds for tobacco regions. Noncompliance results in a reduction of the allotted amount by 10-30% for fiscal years 2010-2012. For fiscal years 2010-2012, noncompliance with regulations may result in a reduction of allotted funds by 10-30%. Starting from fiscal year 2013, the reduction may increase to 40% if the State is found to be noncompliant. Additionally, a further 10% reduction may apply if the State fails to meet certain compliance criteria. Starting from fiscal year 2010, States may face reductions in funds for noncompliance with regulations, with potential increases in reductions up to 40% by fiscal year 2013. The Secretary will provide assistance in implementing State laws and setting goals for compliance. The term 'first applicable fiscal year' is defined for different States. The amendment made by subsection (a) will apply from the first applicable fiscal year onwards. The provisions of section 1926 of the Public Health Service Act will apply to fiscal years before the first applicable fiscal year. The term "first applicable fiscal year" is defined in subsection (g) of the Act. SEC. 3. PUBLIC DISCLOSURE OF INGREDIENTS. The Federal Cigarette Labeling and Advertising Act is amended to make ingredient information accessible to the public online within 48 hours of submission to the Secretary.
